***UPDATED REVIEW***

PIPE by BMX Streets is the first actual BMX game that comes close to scratching that itch we all had for a spinoff of EA's abandoned Skate franchise. Instead of using the button based tricks of the Dave Mirra and Mat Hoffman games, PIPE uses the right analog stick to shift your weight or control the direction of the tricks, the triggers and bumpers controlling your feet and hands, left stick for steering and rotation, and the A button to pedal. Although the controls can be overwhileming when you first start the game up, that is part of the charm. Learning how to pull off different tricks and landing them smoothly is incredibly satisfying. 

This game does feature a small tutorial, but the bulk of your time is probably going to be spent in the titular Pipe arena, which is a large half pipe with a few ramps and rails thrown around the outside of the park that can lead to some creative lines. I do wish the area was bigger, but there is still plenty of fun to be had just trying to come up with new lines, gaps, or just working on nailing the different tricks.

It is very very very important to mention that this is essentially a demo for the full game, so by purchasing this, you are supporting the developer and development of the upcoming BMX Streets game. Although there is only one park and the tutorial, there's still a lot of fun to be had here as long as you have the imagination. If you've read this far, it's probably worth a purchase for you.  


***ORIGINAL REVIEW***
If you are really into BMX, this might be for you.

As a skater, a fan of extreme sports games, a person following Session, and a huge Skate series fan, I was kind of disappointed by this. I think the controls in this game offer the complexity you need for something like this, and learning how to do tricks, pump, pedalling, and setting up lines is extremely fun.

The reason for the thumbs down is the lack of content. I am aware that this is being pitched as a demo, but (apples and oranges, I know), the free Session demo offers about as much content as this does. The tutorial that is included is kind of unintuitive, which is the opposite of what a tutorial should be. After completing the first objective, it should just go straight to the next one. I could let that slide. What is a bummer is that the tutorial only teaches you the absolute fundamentals of the controls, and the in game menu doesnt show you how the trick system actually works. The screen is there, but all the controls are listed as N/A. 

I was able to look this up online and find videos of people playing another build of the game to solve that issue. That still doesn't excuse the lack of content for the asking price. The Pipe park has a giant half pipe that is fun to ride, but the rest of the park feels a bit bare. It has a few pyramids, some ledges, some rails, and a few quarter pipes, but after I did a few lines, I was left wanting a bit more.

I think this game would geatly benefit from putting out a free demo. If I had tried the BMX Streets Physics demo (which is no longer available) and THEN seen this, I would have been excited about this. However, as a standalone product, this is probably not for most people, unless you are extremely into BMX. It seems promising, and I'm looking forward to whatever BMX Streets ends up being, but it's just a bit barren and kind of buggy for my $10.

PIPE shows a lot of promise. It's essentially wanting to do for BMX what the Skate series did for skateboarding and from what I've seen so far, it can definitely get there. There are only two parks: one training area and one area with a large vert ramp, a few other quarter pipes and mini ramps, and a few boxes and rails. So don't expect to purchase this and have an entire world to explore, because it's not at that point yet.

However, the controls are fantastic. Like the Skate series, they take a bit of getting used to since nothing like this has been done before. But they really allow for almost any trick you can think up.

And most importantly, the developer, Mash Games, is extremely active. You can join the PIPE discord server to give feedback and even direct message him. He's super responsive and grateful to the people who have purchased the game so far, which we need more of in the development community. For that reason alone, I have no hesitation throwing $10 his way to support the project.
